title: TIPS TO MAKE IT WORK BEST FOR YOUR FOUNDATION PHASE
description: When encountering challenging vocabulary, gently push yourself to annotate context clues and paraphrase sentences aloud to deepen understanding without creating stress—this steady approach will build your confidence with nuanced words over time.

Incorporate a variety of transition types into your practice writing by setting small goals to use one new transition word or phrase per paragraph, framing this as a light challenge to enhance flow without disrupting your calm study rhythm.

Regularly outline the structure of passages by briefly noting each paragraph’s purpose and transitions; this deliberate reflection will help you recognize logical flow and improve your ability to answer structure questions with ease.

Visualize nonlinear function graphs before solving problems, and set incremental goals to master one solving technique at a time—this micro-challenge approach balances steady progress with manageable growth beyond your comfort zone.

When working on systems of linear equations, gamify your practice by timing yourself to translate word problems into equations accurately, rewarding yourself for each correct setup to maintain motivation without pressure.

Approach systems involving linear and quadratic equations by pairing algebraic substitution practice with occasional group problem-solving sessions with peers who push your pace slightly, helping you stretch your skills while preserving your balanced study style.
